speaker: Georgie
text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Georgie.

speaker: Neil
text: And I'm Neil. In this programme we're talking about the immune system, which is the body's natural defence against getting ill. Now, Georgie, is there anything you do to boost your immune system?

speaker: Georgie
text: Yes. I try to eat lots of oranges, which apparently have lots of vitamin C, and there are lots of things people do to try to improve their immune system, and stay healthier, like eating certain foods, taking vitamins, or even activities like swimming in cold water. We'll find out how useful some of these techniques are in today's programme.

speaker: Neil
text: But first, Georgie, a question. We all know the common cold – now, that’s the illness that makes you cough and sneeze, have a sore throat and headache. But how many colds does the average adult get in the UK each year? Is it:

speaker: Georgie
text: Eight would be a lot. I'm going to go with a) 2-3 colds a year.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, we'll find out at the end of the programme if you're right. Now, many people can become ill over the winter with diseases like colds, flu and Covid-19. Host of BBC Radio 4 programme Inside Health, James Gallagher, gathered some experts to talk about immune systems, and he started off by asking whether they'd had more illnesses than usual this winter.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: Hello! [Hi.] Right, how has everyone been this winter? Because I've had a rotten one and I have felt constantly ill since about November. John?

speaker: touch wood
text: I have not had anything yet, touch wood.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: OK, let's see what I can infect you with by the end of the show. Margaret?

speaker: snuffles
text: I was pretty unwell in September. I had what I presume to be Covid. But I've been alright since, mild snuffles aside.

speaker: back me up
text: Eleanor, I really need someone to back me up.

speaker: tickety-boo
text: No, sorry, I've been absolutely 100% tickety-boo.

speaker: touch wood
text: Unlike James, Professor John Tregoning hasn't been ill. John uses the expression touch wood, which is an informal phrase said in order to avoid bad luck.

speaker: snufflesSnufflessniffles
text: Doctor Margaret McCartney was unwell in September but has only had a few snuffles since. Snuffles is an informal word used to describe minor illnesses that affect your nose. We can also say sniffles.

speaker: back me upback you up
text: Host James is surprised that nobody has been ill, and says to Professor Eleanor Riley 'back me up'. If you ask someone to back you up, you are asking for them to say something which supports your opinion.

speaker: tickety-boo
text: But Eleanor has had a healthy winter too. She's been tickety-boo, which is an informal phrase meaning everything's fine or in good order.

speaker: Georgie
text: Throughout the winter, many people try different techniques, like taking supplements or eating certain foods to boost their immune system, to improve their body's natural defences against disease. Host of BBC Radio 4's Inside Health James Gallagher asks doctor Margaret McCartney whether some of these products are successful.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: OK quick-fire round Margaret. Echinacea?

speaker: Margaret McCartney
text: No.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: Turmeric?

speaker: Margaret McCartney
text: No.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: Ginger shots?

speaker: Margaret McCartney
text: No.

speaker: James Gallagher
text: This is a very, very good quiz! What about the stuff you squirt up your nose when you're at the beginning of an infection?

speaker: Margaret McCartney
text: Interesting, but not any better than normal saline spray – just salt water.

speaker: Neil
text: In fact, according to Margaret, there isn't enough evidence that many popular health products can actually change the way your immune system works.

speaker: Georgie
text: Another popular health trend in the UK is cold water swimming. People who swim in cold water say it's good for their mental health, and they also believe it makes them less likely to get ill during the winter months.

speaker: Neil
text: But scientists aren't sure about the benefits of cold water swimming for the immune system yet, as Professor John Tregoning explains to BBC Radio 4’s Inside Health.

speaker: dampens more prone to
text: The social element actually is really important. It probably is beneficial to do. You reduce stress and cortisol dampens the immune system, so actually if you're stressed then maybe you are more prone to infection. And that may be why that benefit of being with people, nice people that you like in nice places, is helping. But I don’t think it's unique to cold water swimming. I think you could probably get it from dancing or singing or going for a run.

speaker: dampensdampensdampen someone’s spirits
text: John says that cortisol, a chemical associated with stress, dampens the immune system. Here, dampens means makes weaker. We also have a common expression 'dampen someone’s spirits' which means to make them less enthusiastic about something.

speaker: prone  prone to
text: John says that there is evidence that people who are stressed are more prone to infection. If you're more prone to something, it’s more likely to happen to you.

speaker: Georgie
text: It could be that cold water swimming reduces stress, and so it helps people’s immune systems work well. But there are lots of other activities that could have the same effect, and help people have fewer colds over winter.

speaker: Neil
text: Which reminds me of my question, Georgie. I asked how many colds the average UK adult has a year.

speaker: Georgie
text: And I said 2-3.

speaker: Neil
text: And that is the correct answer, so well done!

speaker: touch wood
text: Thank you! OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with touch wood, which is an expression used, often in speech, to avoid bad luck.

speaker: Snufflessniffles
text: Snuffles, or sniffles, are minor illnesses that affect your nose.

speaker: back you up,
text: If you ask someone to back you up, you want them to say something to support your opinion.

speaker: tickety-boo
text: The expression tickety-boo means fine and in good order.

speaker: dampendampen someone's spirits
text: If you dampen something you make it weaker. And the expression dampen someone's spirits means you make them less enthusiastic about something.

speaker: prone to
text: And if you're more prone to something, it's more likely to happen to you.

speaker: Georgie
text: Once again our 6 minutes are up, but you can test what you've learned with the free interactive quiz on our website.

speaker: Neil
text: Bye for now.

speaker: Georgie
text: Goodbye!
